awd_abstract_narration:
Addressing the scientific software challenges facing the nation requires broad collaboration to foster practices, processes, and tools to improve software developer productivity and software sustainability.  Both of those are key aspects of ensuring the integrity of computational results and increasing scientific productivity. The Better Scientific Software (BSSw) Fellowship Program, launched in 2018 with support from the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE), provides recognition and funding for leaders and advocates of high-quality scientific software.  This project will enable NSF to collaborate in sponsorship of the BSSw Fellowship Program and participate in managing the program.  The project will be piloted in the current year with NSF support of one BSSw Fellow and one Honorable Mention, with the goal of expanding in future years to 2 or more BSSw Fellows and Honorable Mentions.  The BSSw fellow will receive a stipend that can be used for various activities that promote improved scientific software, such as organizing a workshop or creating a tutorial.  Both the BSSw fellow and the honorable mention receive travel support to work with scientific community members and form a cohort.

The National Science Foundation (NSF) and DOE are leaders in advanced computing, pushing the growth of computational and data-enabled science and engineering as an essential driver of scientific and technological progress. Moreover, NSF and DOE researchers have developed a wide range of high-impact scientific software for advanced modeling, simulation, discovery, and analysis. The country faces a software crisis, however, due to disruptive changes in computer architectures and increasing complexity in next-generation computational science.  NSF partnership in sponsoring the BSSw Fellowship Program will enable a more robust approach toward pioneering the future of advanced computing ecosystems in support of American leadership in science and engineering. An important element of the project is exploring the feasibility to expand the program to more fully address the NSF scientific community. The BSSw Fellowship Program enhances workforce development and pathways to the NSF and DOE software communities, though nurturing a network of people who advance software practices as a fundamental aspect of increasing overall scientific productivity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Version control is an essential tool for collaborative work on software, but domain scientists lack the knowledge they need to contribute to these efforts. There are only a handful of developers who have the skills needed to work collaboratively on software and this limits the sustainability of software efforts that are increasingly crucial to their communities. Existing version control training materials focus either on the underlying theory or a comprehensive overview of version control. Such material can be inaccessible to new developers if they cannot identify what information is applicable to their specific problem.

This project added to the existing ecosystem of training materials and worked to fill a gap that is not well addressed currently. This gap is convincing scientists that version control can be valuable and is worth the effort and time required to learn about it. This project enabled collaborative work on scientific software through user-focused version control materials and tutorials. Using illustration/posters provides a unique way to teach and learn. Most existing materials in this realm are very text-heavy and hard to understand, and they do not emphasize user stories as a base.

This project developed accessible, user-focused tutorials on version control that give scientists the information they need to contribute to shared software. The version control tutorials center around common user stories and directly address how a scientist should interact with version control to work collaboratively in common science scenarios. The project commissioned and tested art illustrations alongside the tutorials to determine if new users could translate everyday concepts into the equivalent version control terms.

The opportunities for training and professional development arising from this project include providing artists with opportunities to collaborate on technical illustration projects; developing enhanced awareness about low-impact processes to invite contributors to software repositories; providing opportunities for early-career scientists to gain knowledge regarding version control; and increasing knowledge regarding pathways to assess project effectiveness focused on teaching and learning technical skills. Educators who want or require their students to use version control in the classroom or for research projects will have another resource in which to point students. A resource that aims to present material differently, focuses on human interactions and motivations, and is designed to motivate viewers to learn more on their own.

Opening software development to a broader community means we need to offer more diverse approaches to learning the tools. The project developed stories through illustration to explain essential operations in the git version control tool. Under this grant, the major outcomes included: identification for user stories that are common across several research groups; developed art that focused on three high-requested use stories; tested protocols to determine the effectiveness of art; and contributed to guidelines to foster sustainable contributions and collaborations.

 

Products developed can be viewed:

  • Poster, “The time to commit is now!”, VersionControl_NowIsAGreatTimeToCommit_Web.jpg · main · git-stories / Commit Early And Often · GitLab

  • Poster, “Some moments are worth keeping”, VersionControl_SomeMomentsAreWorthKeeping_Web.jpg · main · git-stories / Commit Guide · GitLab

  • Poster, “Every commit requires a comment”, VersionControl_EveryCommitRequiresAComment_Web.jpg · main · git-stories / Every Commit Requires Comments · GitLab
